questions.question_text:
A field alias is created where field1 = field2 and the Overwrite Field Values checkbox is selected.

What happens if an event only contains values for field1?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
I tested, D correct ans

Selected Answer: C
Option C is more correct:
Explanation:
In Splunk, if an event has values for only one field (like field1) and not for another field (like field2), then the values of field2 remain unchanged in the context of that particular event. Field2 will still retain whatever values it has from previous events or selections if it is present. 

Here’s a breakdown of the other options for clarification:

A. field1 and field2 values are merged.: This is incorrect. There is no merging of values; each field retains its own values independently.

B. field2 values are removed from the events.: This is incorrect. Values for field2 are not removed; they simply are not present in this specific event.

D. field2 values are replaced with the value of field1.: This is incorrect. Values in field2 are not replaced by any value from field1 unless specifically programmed to do so with a command.

Selected Answer: D
Select Overwrite field values if you want your field alias to remove the field alias name when the original field does not exist or has no value, or replace the field alias name with the original field name when the field alias name already exists.
REF: https://kinneygroup.com/blog/splunk-fields-of-dreams-how-to-create-calculated-fields-and-aliases/#:~:text=(Optional)%20Select%20Overwrite%20field%20values,Click%20Save.

choices.A: field1 and field2 values are merged.
choices.D: field2 values are replaced with the value of the field1.
choices.B: field2 values are removed from the events.

questions.question_text: A data model consists of which three types of datasets?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Data model can consist of 3 types of datasets - Events, Searches and Transactions so B is correct answer.
Per F2 pdf, Data model can consist of 3 types of datasets - Events, Searches and Transactions so B is correct answer.

Selected Answer: C
https://docs.splunk.com/Documentation/Splunk/9.4.1/Knowledge/Acceleratedatamodels
When you run a tstats search on an accelerated data model where the search has a time range that extends past the summarization time range of the data model, the search will generate results from the summarized data within that time range and from the unsummarized data that falls outside of that time range.

Selected Answer: D
When a data model is accelerated, Splunk precomputes a summary of the data model to improve search performance. This affects how it can be queried:

questions.question_text: Which of the following is true about a datamodel that has been accelerated?

choices.D: They can be used with the |tstats command, but will only return that data which has been accelerated.
choices.A: They can no longer be used in the Pivot tool.
choices.C: They can be used with Pivot, the |tstats command, or the |datamodel command.
choices.B: They can still be used in the Pivot tool but only with the accelerate_pivot capability.

choices.A: The maxspan option is not included.
choices.D: The transaction command has a limit of 1000 events per transaction.
choices.B: The stats list () function is used.
choices.C: The transaction and stats commands cannot be used together.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
I believe that “B” is the correct answer to this question. The “maxspan” is optional when you use “transaction”.

As the example uses a “stats list” and a “sum”, what you get in return is a listing with the number of events that have been logged from those IPs in Splunk and performs a total sum of events for each IP.

choices.B: Every event in the network index that does not contain a StatusCode of 200 and excluding events that do not have a value in this field.
choices.C: Every event in the network index that does not contain a StatusCode of 200, including events that do not have a value in this field.
choices.A: No results as the syntax is incorrect, the != field expression needs to be used instead of the NOT operator.
choices.D: Every event in the network index that does not have a value in this field.

questions.question_text:
What are the expected search results from executing the following SPL command?

index=network NOT StatusCode=200

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
Correct, "C"is the good answer.

When you want to exclude results from your search you can use the NOT operator or the != field expression. However there is a significant difference in the results that are returned from these two methods.

If you search with the != expression, every event that has a value in the field, where that value does not match the value you specify, is returned. Events that do not have a value in the field are not included in the results.

If you search with the NOT operator, every event is returned except the events that contain the value you specify. This includes events that do not have a value in the field.

Reference: https://docs.splunk.com/Documentation/Splunk/latest/Search/NOTexpressions
